head.headtext: Character evidence—Criminal cases—Character of the victim

para.paratext: Generally, character of the victim is irrelevant and inadmissible[1] because it is just as unlawful to commit a crime against a person of bad character as it is to commit a crime against a person of good character. The admissibility of a victim's character is governed by O.C.G.A. §§ 24-4-404 and 24-4-405.[2] Thus, character evidence of a victim is generally limited to reputation evidence and not specific bad acts.[3]

One exception to this rule is evidence of the deceased's violent nature when the defendant in a homicide prosecution claims his act was justified because the deceased was the first aggressor.[4] In such cases, “[t]he threshold rule is that the character of the victim (general or specific) is inadmissible unless it is shown prima facie [1] that the deceased was the assailant, [2] that the defendant was being assailed, and [3] that the defendant was honestly seeking to defend himself.”[5] When this prima facie test is met, general reputation evidence about the victim is admissible.[6]

For evidence of a victim's violent nature to be admissible, the prior instances of conduct must actually show a violent tendency and not just bad character.[7] “Evidence that impugns a victim's character cannot be admitted unless it has some factual nexus with the conclusion for which it is being offered.”[8] Thus, “evidence of drug use is inadmissible when it is intended only to impugn a victim's character and has no relevance to any disputed issues in the case.”[9]

Evidence of the general violent nature of the defendant, in the form of his Facebook posts, is not admissible under Rules 404 and 405 because said posts were not limited to reputation or opinion evidence. Moreover, said posts were offered by the state in their case-in-chief; thus, the timing did not comply with the method set out under the rules under Revere.[10] Rule 404 deals with whether the evidence can be admitted, and Rule 405 deals with the methods by which the evidence may be proved.[11]

The prosecution may rebut evidence of a victim's violent nature with evidence of a victim's peaceful nature.[12] A victim who testifies at trial is subject to impeachment like any other witness. The same reasoning applied to admit evidence of a victim's violent nature may also be applied to other character traits of a victim, assuming such traits are relevant and material to issues in the case such as motive, opportunity, entrapment, or identity.[13]

In Milton v. State,[14] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the deceased's specific prior acts of violence toward the defendant were admissible to show that he reasonably believed it was necessary to shoot the victim before she shot him. Thus, “[w]here the evidence tends to prove that the accused acted in self-defense, evidence of the violent and dangerous character of the deceased, known to the defendant, is admissible as tending to characterize the acts of the deceased, as bearing on the reasonableness of defendant's apprehension of danger at the time of the homicide.”[15] The court recognized some reasons why such evidence may be excluded: “(1) A single act may have been exceptional, unusual, and not characteristic and thus a specific act does not necessarily establish one's general character; (2) although the state is bound to foresee that the general character of the deceased may be put in issue, it cannot anticipate and prepare to rebut each and every specific act of violence; and (3) permitting proof of specific acts would multiply the issues, prolong the trial and confuse the jury.”[16] In Milton, the Court quoted Justice Lumpkin from Baker v. State[17] about when there is a lapse of time between the prior events and the crime at issue:

The general rule is that circumstances showing previous difficulties or encounters between the accused and the deceased are relevant, where such circumstances have an obvious connection with, or serve to explain, the facts and circumstances of the homicide charge on trial. The length of time intervening is only material as affecting the credibility and weight to be given to such evidence. Where the difficulty is followed by continuous hostility or a disposition to renew at every opportunity, the weight of the testimony is correspondingly increased. Where the difficulty is temporary or followed by a cessation of hostilities, or former peaceful relations had been resumed, the circumstances of the previous difficulties are of little value.

Accordingly, “[i]n cases of doubt as to whether or not evidence of prior difficulties should be admitted, the evidence should be admitted and its credibility and weight should be decided by the jury.”[18]

The Georgia Supreme Court considered the issue of a defendant offering evidence of specific acts of violence by a victim toward a third person in Lolley v. State,[19] and affirmed the line of cases excluding such evidence. However, in special concurrence, Justice Weltner explained why the Supreme Court should change the rule because “a decedent's violent acts against a third party can be as relevant as his violent acts against a defendant in weighing the truth of a defendant's claim of justification.” Subsequently, in Chandler v. State,[20] the Georgia Supreme Court adopted his reasoning and held that evidence of specific acts of violence by a victim against third persons shall be admissible when the defendant claims justification.

In Daniel v. State,[21] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that evidence of a victim's specific acts of violence would be irrelevant where the defense was accident and that evidence of violent acts by a victim should be limited to those which occurred before the alleged crime. However, Judge Carley, relying on Justice Weltner's reasoning in Lolley, supra, opined that violent acts occurring after the crime should be admissible as relevant to the defendant's credibility regarding the victim's violent nature. Since Daniel, courts have followed Judge Carley's reasoning on this issue.[22] For evidence of a victim's violent nature to be admissible, the prior instances of conduct must actually show a violent tendency and not just bad character.[23]

Overruling the evidentiary rule set out in Chandler, the Supreme Court in 2015 held that permitting a defendant claiming justification to introduce evidence of specific acts of violence by the victim against third persons is no longer viable under Georgia's new Evidence Code. In Mohamud v. State,[24] the Supreme Court declined to follow Chandler, where the defendant argued the trial court erred by excluding evidence that the victim had committed a violent robbery against a third party. The Court held that, as a general rule, character evidence of the victim is limited to reputation or opinion, not specific bad acts.

Maynor v. State, 241 Ga. 315, 245 S.E.2d 268 (1978) (citing Doyal v. State, 70 Ga. 134, 148, 1883 WL 2886 (1883); Baker v. State, 142 Ga. 619, 622, 83 S.E. 531 (1914); and Henderson v. State, 234 Ga. 827, 828, 218 S.E.2d 612 (1975)).

O.C.G.A § 24-4-404(a)(2) states “Evidence of a person's character or a trait of character shall not be admissible for the purpose of proving action in conformity therewith on a particular occasion, except for: … (2) Subject to the limitations imposed by Code Section 24-4-412, evidence of a pertinent trait of character of the alleged victim of the crime offered by an accused or by the prosecution to rebut the same; or evidence of a character trait of peacefulness of the alleged victim offered by the prosecution in a homicide case to rebut evidence that the alleged victim was the first aggressor.”

O.C.G.A. § 24-4-405(a) further provides: “In all proceedings in which evidence of character or a trait of character of a person is admissible, proof shall be made by testimony as to reputation or by testimony in the form of an opinion.” Therefore, as a general rule, character evidence of a victim is limited to reputation or opinion, not specific bad acts.
Wofford v. State, 305 Ga. 694, 827 S.E.2d 652 (2019).

This exception is usually applied in cases in which the accused claims self defense; however, it has also been held that a defendant could show “battered woman syndrome” as matter of defense to show her fear of the victim. Smith v. State, 247 Ga. 612, 277 S.E.2d 678, 18 A.L.R.4th 1144 (1981). In Mondragon v. State, 304 Ga. 843, 823 S.E.2d 276 (2019), the Georgia Supreme Court held that it is error for a trial court to admit evidence of a victim's good character in anticipation of the defendant's introducing contrary evidence at trial; however, the Court held that in this case, the error was harmless because the defendant's sole defense was that the victims were the first aggressors.

See also Black v. State, 230 Ga. 614, 198 S.E.2d 314 (1973); Davis v. State, 158 Ga. App. 594, 281 S.E.2d 344 (1981); Curtis v. State, 241 Ga. 125, 243 S.E.2d 859 (1978) (not admissible under facts of case); Anderson v. State, 250 Ga. 451, 298 S.E.2d 496 (1983).
A prima facie showing had been made in Dill v. State, 254 Ga. 17, 325 S.E.2d 765 (1985).
In Bennett v. State, 254 Ga. 162, 326 S.E.2d 438 (1985), a prima facie showing probably had not been made, but in any event specific acts against third persons would not be admissible.
In Sawyer v. State, 161 Ga. App. 479, 288 S.E.2d 108 (1982), the foundation had been laid to the extent that the trial judge would permit, so the evidence should have been admitted.

As held in Melear v. State, 159 Ga. App. 574, 284 S.E.2d 79 (1981), when a prima facie showing of the foundation has been made, the evidence should be admitted and the trial judge should not weigh the credibility of the evidence.
The victim's character for peacefulness was properly shown in Dixon v. State, 243 Ga. 46, 252 S.E.2d 431 (1979).
Evidence that the victim was on probation was not admissible in a murder trial. Butler v. State, 254 Ga. 637, 332 S.E.2d 654 (1985).
Henderson v. State, 234 Ga. 827, 218 S.E.2d 612 (1975) (general reputation for shooting people was admissible).

In the case of In Interest of J.R.F., 182 Ga. App. 713, 356 S.E.2d 747 (1987), the court held that the general reputation of the victim for violence could be shown by witnesses other than the defendant and that the defendant need not have had knowledge of such reputation. But this type of evidence should only be introduced after a defendant tenders evidence of a pertinent case of the victim, and not before. Revere v. State, 302 Ga. 44, 805 S.E.2d 69 (2017)

See Smith v. State, 270 Ga. 240, 510, 510 S.E.2d 1 (1998) (overruled on other grounds by, O'Kelley v. State, 284 Ga. 758, 670 S.E.2d 388 (2008)) (prior shotgun possession offense was not relevant since there was no evidence that anyone was ever harmed); Bennett v. State, 265 Ga. 38, 40–41, 453 S.E.2d 458 (1995) (victim's prior convictions for burglary not admissible as previous acts of violence against a third party because there was no evidence that anyone was harmed); Lowe v. State, 267 Ga. 410, 414, 478 S.E.2d 762 (1996) (threats and menaces do not constitute previous acts of violence under Chandler).
Roseberry v. State, 274 Ga. 301, 303, 553 S.E.2d 589 (2001).

See also Bell v. State, 280 Ga. 562, 629 S.E.2d 213 (2006) (evidence victim's prior drug use was evidence was too attenuated to warrant speculation about the effects of cocaine on the victim at the time of the shooting).
Revere v. State, 302 Ga. 44, 805 S.E.2d 69 (2017).
Timmons v. State, 302 Ga. 464, 807 S.E.2d 363 (2017).

See Austin v. State, 268 Ga. 602, 492 S.E.2d 212 (1997) (Citing Crawley v. State, 137 Ga. 777, 779, 74 S.E. 537 (1912): “Where the defendant has offered evidence of threats against himself made by the deceased, the prosecution has been permitted to introduce evidence of the good character of the latter.”).
See Hanson v. State, 143 Ga. App. 200, 237 S.E.2d 699 (1977); Parker v. State, 281 Ga. 490, 640 S.E.2d 44 (2007); Hand v. Pettitt, 258 Ga. App. 170, 573 S.E.2d 421 (2002).
Milton v. State, 245 Ga. 20, 262 S.E.2d 789 (1980).
Milton v. State, 245 Ga. 20, 23–24, 262 S.E.2d 789 (1980) (quoting Baker v. State, 142 Ga. 619, 83 S.E. 531 (1914)).
Lolley v. State, 259 Ga. 605, 385 S.E.2d 285 (1989); Burden v. State, 332 Ga. App. 811, 775 S.E.2d 183 (2015).
Chandler v. State, 261 Ga. 402, 405 S.E.2d 669 (1991).
See Ochle v. State, 218 Ga. App. 69, 73, 459 S.E.2d 560 (1995) (“[I]t is not essential that the specific act occurred prior to the act being tried.”).

State, 265 Ga. 38, 40–41, 453 S.E.2d 458 (1995) (victim's prior convictions for burglary not admissible as previous acts of violence against a third party because there was no evidence that anyone was harmed); Lowe v.
